trigger: Chest pain atypical presentation non-cardiac cardiac differential diagnosis
strategy: Classify chest pain characteristics (quality, location, radiation, duration, triggers, relieving factors)
Identify red flags for life-threatening causes (cardiac, pulmonary, aortic)
Assess cardiovascular risk factors (age, diabetes, hypertension, smoking, family history)
Evaluate for associated symptoms (dyspnea, syncope, diaphoresis, palpitations)
Compare presentation to typical patterns of common diagnoses (ACS vs GERD vs musculoskeletal)
Use validated clinical prediction rules (HEART, TIMI, Wells' for PE) to guide diagnostic testing

evidenceBase.citation: Amsterdam EA, et al. 2014 AHA/ACC guideline for the management of patients with non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes. Circulation. 2014
evidenceBase.relevance: Risk stratification and diagnostic approach for suspected ACS

evidenceBase.citation: Fanaroff AC, et al. Does This Patient With Chest Pain Have Acute Coronary Syndrome? JAMA. 2015
Mahler SA, et al. The HEART Pathway: A Risk Stratification Tool for Emergency Department Patients With Chest Pain. JAMA Cardiol. 2022
evidenceBase.relevance: Validation of the HEART score for early discharge

cautions: Women, elderly, and diabetic patients may present with atypical symptoms of ACS
Normal ECG and initial troponin do not exclude ACS
Gastroesophageal and musculoskeletal causes often diagnoses of exclusion
Panic disorder and anxiety can mimic symptoms of ACS but remain diagnoses of exclusion
Cognitive biases (availability, anchoring) contribute to missed diagnoses

example.presentation: 45-year-old female with burning central chest pain for 2 days, worse after meals and when lying down. No dyspnea, diaphoresis or radiation. History of GERD and anxiety. Normal vital signs, ECG shows normal sinus rhythm.
example.application: Pattern application identifies low-risk features using HEART score (2 points). History suggests GERD exacerbation rather than ACS. Testing includes single troponin (negative) and trial of antacid therapy with significant symptom improvement.
example.outcome: Patient diagnosed with GERD exacerbation, discharged with PPI therapy and outpatient follow-up. No cardiac events at 30-day follow-up.
